title: Fundamental Analysis Deep Dive
description: Learn to evaluate company financial health, analyze financial statements, and calculate key ratios to identify undervalued stocks.
objectives: Read and interpret financial statements (Balance Sheet, P&L, Cash Flow)
Calculate and analyze key financial ratios
Perform company valuation using PE, PB, DCF methods
Identify quality businesses for long-term investing

lessons.title: Reading Financial Statements
lessons.videoTopic: Balance Sheet, P&L, Cash Flow Statement Explained

content.original: Three key financial statements: Balance Sheet shows assets, liabilities, equity at a point in time. Profit & Loss (P&L) shows revenue, expenses, profit over period. Cash Flow Statement tracks actual cash inflows/outflows. Together they reveal company's financial health. Assets = Liabilities + Equity. Revenue - Expenses = Net Profit. Operating, Investing, Financing cash flows must be analyzed.
content.simplified: Balance Sheet = What company owns (assets) and owes (liabilities) on specific date. P&L = How much company earned (revenue) and spent (expenses) over time period. Cash Flow = Actual cash coming in and going out. Profit doesn't always mean cash in hand. A company can show profit but have no cash (accounting vs reality).

lessons.aiSummary: 3 Statements: Balance Sheet (Assets, Liabilities, Equity snapshot), P&L (Revenue, Expenses, Profit over time), Cash Flow (Actual cash movements). Profit â‰  Cash always.
keyTakeaways: Balance Sheet = Snapshot on specific date
P&L = Performance over period (quarterly/yearly)
Positive cash flow more important than accounting profit
All three statements interconnected
commonMistakes: Focusing only on P&L, ignoring balance sheet and cash flow
Assuming profit means company has cash

lessons.title: Key Financial Ratios
lessons.videoTopic: PE, PB, ROE, Debt-to-Equity, Current Ratio

content.original: Valuation ratios: PE (Price-to-Earnings) = Market price / EPS, shows how much investors pay per rupee of earnings. PB (Price-to-Book) = Market price / Book value per share. Profitability: ROE (Return on Equity) = Net profit / Shareholder equity, measures efficiency. Debt ratios: Debt-to-Equity shows leverage. Liquidity: Current ratio = Current assets / Current liabilities, measures ability to pay short-term obligations.
content.simplified: PE ratio tells if stock is expensive or cheap compared to earnings. Low PE might mean undervalued (or company has problems). High PE might mean overvalued (or high growth expected). ROE shows how efficiently company uses shareholder money - higher is better. Debt-to-Equity shows how much company relies on loans - too high is risky. Current ratio shows if company can pay bills coming due soon.

lessons.aiSummary: PE = Price/Earnings (valuation). PB = Price/Book. ROE = Profit/Equity (efficiency). Debt-to-Equity (leverage risk). Current Ratio = Assets/Liabilities (liquidity). Compare with peers and industry.
keyTakeaways: No single ratio tells complete story - use multiple ratios
Compare ratios with industry peers, not across industries
ROE >15% generally considered good in India
Debt-to-Equity <1 typically safer
commonMistakes: Using PE ratio alone to judge stock (context matters)
Ignoring trends - single year data insufficient

lessons.title: Company Valuation Methods
lessons.videoTopic: DCF, PE Valuation, Intrinsic Value Calculation

content.original: Discounted Cash Flow (DCF): Project future cash flows and discount to present value using WACC (Weighted Average Cost of Capital). Intrinsic value = sum of discounted future cash flows. PE-based valuation: Intrinsic value = Expected EPS Ã— Justified PE. Compare intrinsic value to market price. Margin of safety: Buy only if market price significantly below intrinsic value. Different methods give different values - use multiple approaches.
content.simplified: Intrinsic value = What stock is actually worth based on company's ability to generate cash. DCF method: Estimate how much cash company will generate in future, then calculate what that's worth today. PE method: Multiply expected earnings by fair PE ratio. If intrinsic value is â‚¹500 but market price is â‚¹350, stock might be undervalued. Always build in margin of safety - don't pay â‚¹490 even if value is â‚¹500.

PE valuation simpler but depends on choosing right PE multiple
Never pay more than intrinsic value
30-40% margin of safety recommended
commonMistakes: Being too optimistic in growth projections (garbage in, garbage out)
Using single valuation method (triangulate with multiple)
Not updating valuation as new information emerges

lessons.title: Competitive Advantages and Moats

content.original: Economic moat = Sustainable competitive advantage protecting company from competition. Types: Brand moat (Coca-Cola, Apple), Network effects (Facebook, PayTM), Cost advantages (Walmart, Amazon), Switching costs (SAP, Microsoft), Intangible assets (patents, licenses). Wide moat companies can maintain high returns on capital. Analyze if advantage is durable (10+ years) or temporary. Moats erode over time - continuous assessment needed.
content.simplified: Moat = Protection that keeps competitors away, like a castle's moat keeps enemies out. Brand moat: People prefer your brand (iPhone users rarely switch to Android). Network moat: More users make product more valuable (WhatsApp). Cost moat: You can produce cheaper than others. Switching cost moat: Too painful for customers to switch (imagine changing all your bank accounts). Companies with strong moats can charge higher prices and earn more profit for many years.

keyTakeaways: Wide moat companies = Better long-term investments
Moats can strengthen or weaken - monitor regularly

lessons.title: Quality Business Checklist

content.original: Quality checklist: (1) Consistent earnings growth (10%+ CAGR), (2) High ROE (>15%) and ROCE (>20%), (3) Low debt or manageable debt levels, (4) Strong free cash flow generation, (5) Honest and competent management, (6) Wide economic moat, (7) Reasonable valuation. Look for businesses you understand (circle of competence). Read annual reports, management commentary, concall transcripts. Red flags: Frequent related-party transactions, auditor changes, pledged promoter holdings.
content.simplified: Great companies checklist: Growing earnings every year, using shareholder money efficiently (high ROE), not drowning in debt, generating actual cash (not just accounting profit), honest management team, strong competitive advantages, and reasonable price. Warren Buffett says invest only in businesses you understand. Read company's annual report like a detective - look for honesty and consistency. Warning signs: Promoters using company money for personal benefit, changing auditors frequently.

lessons.aiSummary: Quality business: Consistent growth, High ROE/ROCE, Low debt, Strong FCF, Honest management, Wide moat, Fair valuation. Invest in circle of competence. Read annual reports. Avoid red flags.
keyTakeaways: All criteria don't need to be perfect - look for overall quality
Management integrity is non-negotiable
Circle of competence: Know what you know and don't know
Annual report reading = Free MBA in business analysis
commonMistakes: Buying based on single quarter results (short-term thinking)
Ignoring management red flags due to attractive valuations
Investing in complex businesses you don't understand
